One of the most extreme endurance rallies outside East Africa, the 1978 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire tested the mechanical limits of rally cars and the physical resolve of competitors. Stretching across harsh terrain, from jungle tracks to remote savannahs, the event demanded durability over outright speed. Jean-Pierre Nicolas and Vincent Laverne’s calm strategy and the Peugeot 504’s famed toughness led them to a dominant victory in this unforgiving African marathon.

🗺️ Route Details

The route looped deep into the Ivorian interior, starting and finishing in Abidjan, and passing through towns like Bouaké, Korhogo, and Man via rugged laterite roads and tropical forests.

  • Central Highlands: Gravel and clay-based roads with deep ruts, loose rocks, and unpredictable traction.
  • Coastal Plains: Faster open sections on worn tarmac mixed with dusty red-earth gravel routes.
  • Jungle Zones: Dense vegetation, narrow paths, and waterlogged surfaces caused significant navigation and mechanical challenges.

The oppressive humidity and long, continuous driving stages meant that survival and steady pacing were the keys to success, rather than aggressive stage times.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jean-Pierre Nicolas & Vincent Laverne (Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé)

2nd Place: Timo Mäkinen & Henry Liddon (Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé)

3rd Place: Bernard Béguin & Jean-Jacques Lenne (Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé)

Peugeot dominated the event with its rugged 504 Coupés, sweeping the podium and reinforcing the brand’s reputation in African endurance rallying.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé: Exceptionally durable and comfortable over long stages, with robust suspension and reliable cooling systems.
  • Nissan Violet: Competitive but suffered under the heat and long stage strain, leading to high attrition.
  • Mercedes-Benz 280E: Strong but less agile and more prone to mechanical fatigue in off-road sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Heat: Interior temperatures soared above 45°C, testing both driver stamina and engine cooling systems.
  • Night Navigation: Poorly marked routes through jungle and savannah required accurate maps and sharp reflexes.
  • Mechanical Survivability: Potholes, riverbeds, and endless corrugations demanded constant vigilance and careful pace.

The 1978 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire was a war of attrition—Nicolas and Laverne’s victory was built on consistency, mechanical sympathy, and a car purpose-built for African endurance challenges.

title: 1978 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Bernard Darniche and Alain Mahé claimed a commanding victory at the 22nd Tour de Corse, mastering the Corsican tarmac in their agile and aggressive Lancia Stratos HF.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 22ème Tour de Corse

Date: November 4–5, 1978

Host Country: France

Surface: Asphalt

Total Distance: ~1,020 km

Total Starters: Approx. 80 crews

Total Finishers: 27 crews

The 1978 Tour de Corse was a true test of precision, endurance, and mental stamina. Known as the “Rally of 10,000 Corners,” the event wound through the mountainous interior and coastal cliffs of Corsica. Bernard Darniche, a specialist on tarmac and a Corsica veteran, took full advantage of the Lancia Stratos HF’s agility and power to dominate the field, delivering another iconic Tour de Corse win alongside Alain Mahé.

🗺️ Route Details

Based in Ajaccio, the route took crews deep into the Corsican highlands with stages crisscrossing narrow, undulating mountain roads and coastal ridgelines.

  • Vizzavona Pass: Elevation changes, hairpins, and slick tarmac kept teams on edge.
  • Castagniccia Region: Twisting roads through dense chestnut forests offered zero room for error.
  • Ajaccio Loops: Fast but technical sections tested concentration as fatigue set in late in the rally.

Dry autumn weather made for consistent grip, though falling leaves and fine gravel occasionally added unpredictability to braking zones and tight corners.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Bernard Darniche & Alain Mahé (Lancia Stratos HF)

2nd Place: Jean-Pierre Nicolas & Vincent Laverne (Peugeot 504 Coupé V6)

3rd Place: Guy Fréquelin & Jacques Delaval (Opel Kadett GT/E)

Darniche’s mastery of Corsican roads and the Stratos’ raw agility proved too much for the competition, extending his legacy on the island’s iconic rally tarmac.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Stratos HF: Mid-engine layout and short wheelbase made it ideal for Corsica’s endless corners and rapid transitions.
  • Peugeot 504 Coupé V6: Powerful and stable, but heavier and less responsive on the tightest technical sections.
  • Opel Kadett GT/E: Lightweight and nimble, but down on outright speed compared to factory entries.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Endless Corners: With few straights, co-drivers had to deliver notes rapidly and rhythmically without mistake.
  • Driver Fatigue: The intense mental load of constant cornering tested even the most seasoned competitors.
  • Minimal Margins: Guardrails were rare and ditches deep—precision was mandatory at all times.

The 1978 Tour de Corse solidified Bernard Darniche’s status as the king of Corsica, with a victory that showcased daring pace, mechanical confidence, and unmatched tarmac technique.

title: 1978 Lombard RAC Rally (United Kingdom)
bio: Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz dominated the 1978 Lombard RAC Rally with a textbook performance in their Ford Escort RS1800, mastering the damp British forests to claim a celebrated WRC victory.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 27th Lombard RAC Rally

Date: November 19–23, 1978

Host Country: United Kingdom

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~2,500 km

Total Starters: Over 160 crews

Total Finishers: 74 crews

The 1978 RAC Rally offered the quintessential British gravel challenge—slick forest stages, fog, mud, and mechanical attrition. With over 70 timed stages across England, Wales, and Scotland, it demanded endurance, sharp reflexes, and reliability. Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz delivered a dominant drive in their Ford Escort RS1800, combining speed and steadiness to take a convincing victory in one of rallying’s most prestigious events.

🗺️ Route Details

The route began in Bath and included legendary forests like Kielder, Hafren, Dalby, and Grizedale, offering a mix of tight technical sections and high-speed gravel blasts through tree-lined roads.

  • Kielder Forest: Long, fast straights with hidden ruts and frequent fog.
  • Hafren & Myherin: Narrow Welsh roads with deep mud and slick descents.
  • Grizedale: Tight and twisty with unpredictable grip and minimal runoff.

Rain and fog were constant factors throughout the event, with stages frequently run in darkness—making light pods, tire strategy, and pace note rhythm absolutely crucial.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Ford Escort RS1800)

2nd Place: Russell Brookes & Mike Broad (Ford Escort RS1800)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Peter Bryant (Ford Escort RS1800)

Ford dominated the event, with the Escort RS1800 sweeping the podium. Mikkola’s control and Hertz’s expert pacenotes gave the pairing a critical advantage across the misty, unpredictable forests of the UK.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS1800: Lightweight, agile, and perfectly suited to the loose, narrow forest roads of Britain.
  • Vauxhall Chevette HS: Strong in straight-line sections, though struggled in traction and consistency under wet conditions.
  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Competitive on wide gravel but less effective in the tighter, muddier stages of Wales and the North.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Fog and Rain: Dense conditions limited visibility and slowed progress on many key stages.
  • Long Schedule: The five-day format and hundreds of kilometers of timed running tested team logistics and driver endurance.
  • Slippery Surfaces: Constant mud and wet leaves made grip levels extremely variable and corner speeds unpredictable.

The 1978 Lombard RAC Rally was a battle of survival and speed—Mikkola’s win solidified his reputation as a master of gravel and a force across the WRC calendar.

title: 1979 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco/France)
bio: Bernard Darniche and Alain Mahé conquered the snow-slicked tarmac of the Alps to win the 1979 Rallye Monte-Carlo in their Lancia Stratos HF, marking one of the most iconic comebacks in rally history.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 47ème Rallye Monte-Carlo

Date: January 20–26, 1979

Host Countries: Monaco / France

Surface: Tarmac / Snow

Total Distance: ~3,000 km

Total Starters: Approx. 230 crews

Total Finishers: 74 crews

The 1979 Rallye Monte-Carlo was one of the most dramatic editions of the legendary event. Challenging winter conditions, treacherous mountain roads, and high-stakes driving defined the rally. Bernard Darniche and Alain Mahé pulled off an extraordinary comeback from 9th place to 1st on the final night, overtaking the field on the snow-covered Col de Turini. Their victory in the Lancia Stratos HF became the stuff of rallying legend.

🗺️ Route Details

Crews departed from multiple European cities and converged on Monaco before tackling iconic Alpine stages such as Col de Braus, Col de Castillon, and the infamous Col de Turini.

  • Col de Turini: Snow, ice, and sheer cliffs tested nerves in the rally's most famous night stage.
  • Col de Braus & Mont des Mules: Fast tarmac interspersed with frozen corners and tire-compromising transitions.
  • La Bollène-Vésubie Loop: Narrow and technical with low visibility and mixed surfaces throughout.

Snowfall was heavy during key stages, making tire selection and local weather intel absolutely critical—those who gambled right gained minutes.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Bernard Darniche & Alain Mahé (Lancia Stratos HF)

2nd Place: Björn Waldegård & Hans Thorszelius (Ford Escort RS1800)

3rd Place: Jean-Pierre Nicolas & Vincent Laverne (Peugeot 504 Coupé V6)

Darniche’s fearless night-time attack on snow and ice sealed a legendary win, with Mahé’s precision pacenotes making the difference in treacherous Alpine conditions.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Stratos HF: Mid-engined balance and aggressive power delivery gave it an edge on twisty tarmac, even in snowy conditions.
  • Ford Escort RS1800: Consistently fast and durable across mixed surfaces, especially when fitted with snow-spec setups.
  • Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé: Heavy but extremely stable—ideal for the long endurance nature of Monte Carlo stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snow vs. Tarmac: Crews often had to run on the wrong tires for stretches—decisions were made hours in advance with limited weather info.
  • Col Night Loop: The final-night attack through Turini and neighboring cols flipped the leaderboard upside down.
  • Public Traffic: In true Monte tradition, early stages still saw occasional civilian interference and unpredictable hazards.

The 1979 Rallye Monte-Carlo is remembered for one of the greatest comebacks in rally history—Darniche and Mahé’s final push is a masterclass in late-stage heroics under Alpine pressure.

title: 1979 Hankiralli (Finland)
bio: Ari Vatanen and Peter Bryant stormed through Finland’s icy forests to win the 1979 Hankiralli in their Ford Escort RS1800, showcasing speed and precision on snow-covered roads.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Hankiralli

Date: March 2–4, 1979

Host Country: Finland

Surface: Snow / Ice

Total Distance: ~1,100 km

Total Starters: Approx. 80 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

The 1979 Hankiralli, or "Snow Rally," was a showcase of Finnish winter rallying—fast forest roads, snowbanks, and razor-sharp pacenotes. Ari Vatanen, a snow-driving specialist, paired with Peter Bryant to dominate the event in their Ford Escort RS1800, combining fearless driving with pinpoint precision to deliver a hometown victory.

🗺️ Route Details

The route wound through central Finland, with stages around Jyväskylä, Äänekoski, and the snowy lake regions, featuring high-speed packed snow and frozen gravel roads.

  • Forest Sprint Stages: Smooth, flowing snow-covered roads with excellent grip on studded tires.
  • Frozen Lakes: Flat-out speed tests across icy plains, with minimal margin for error.
  • Night Loops: Icy descents and quick transitions demanded total confidence in pacenotes under headlamp-only visibility.

Cold and clear winter weather provided ideal snow rally conditions—consistent traction on hard-packed surfaces but punishing consequences for even small mistakes.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Ari Vatanen & Peter Bryant (Ford Escort RS1800)

2nd Place: Pentti Airikkala & Risto Virtanen (Ford Escort RS1800)

3rd Place: Seppo Niittymäki & Jukka Silvasti (Toyota Celica 2000GT)

Vatanen’s flat-out style and deep familiarity with Finnish snow conditions earned him the win, while Bryant’s quick, accurate calling helped maximize speed through blind crests and corners.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS1800: Light and nimble with excellent traction and balance—perfectly suited to Finnish snow.
  • Toyota Celica 2000GT: Strong straight-line pace but more difficult to rotate in tight snow-covered corners.
  • Saab 99 EMS: Stable and durable, but lacking the agility of the Escort on faster flowing sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Studded Tire Setup: Required careful heat management to maintain grip over long stages.
  • Snowbanks: Used as cornering aids—but clipping one too hard could rip off suspension or cause rollovers.
  • Speed vs. Precision: Split-second decisions and flawless pacenotes were the difference between fastest time and disaster.

The 1979 Hankiralli was a masterclass in winter rallying—Vatanen and Bryant’s performance sealed their status as kings of the snow-covered Finnish stages.

title: 1979 Rallye de Portugal Vinho do Porto (Portugal)
bio: Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz triumphed at the 13th Rallye de Portugal, mastering the challenging mix of gravel and tarmac stages in their Ford Escort RS1800.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 13º Rallye de Portugal Vinho do Porto

Date: March 6–11, 1979

Host Country: Portugal

Surface: Mixed Tarmac / Gravel

Total Distance: ~2,100 km

Total Starters: Approx. 120 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

The 1979 Rallye de Portugal lived up to its reputation as one of the most grueling and diverse events on the WRC calendar. With a combination of high-speed gravel, rough mountainous terrain, and twisty tarmac sections, it demanded mechanical durability and driver adaptability. Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz delivered a flawless drive in their Ford Escort RS1800, taking full advantage of their experience to outlast and outpace the field.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally began in Estoril and ventured through central and northern Portugal, including the rugged Serra da Estrela and the dusty backroads of the Douro Valley wine region.

  • Sintra & Arganil: Legendary gravel stages with deep ruts and hanging dust made visibility and traction critical.
  • Porto Region: Rough mountain sections and fast valleys pushed cars to their limits.
  • Asphalt Loops: Sudden transitions between tarmac and gravel challenged suspension and tire strategies.

Weather ranged from dry and dusty in the interior to cool and damp near the coast, forcing teams to adapt setups multiple times across the event.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Ford Escort RS1800)

2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Fiat 131 Abarth)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Peter Bryant (Ford Escort RS1800)

Mikkola’s consistency and Hertz’s reliable co-driving allowed them to pull ahead in treacherous conditions, while rivals faltered under mechanical strain and stage attrition.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS1800: Light, nimble, and durable—well-suited to the variety of conditions found throughout Portugal.
  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Quick on both surfaces but suffered from reliability issues over long loops.
  • Porsche 911 SC: Fast on tarmac but harder to handle on rougher gravel stretches with limited suspension travel.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Changing Surfaces: Stages transitioned between gravel and tarmac with little warning, demanding careful tire choices and driving style shifts.
  • Dust & Visibility: Thick dust hung in valleys, reducing vision to just a few meters in some key competitive sections.
  • Road Erosion: Rain prior to the event left many gravel tracks deeply rutted and hazardous to suspension components.

The 1979 Rallye de Portugal was a brutal test of endurance and focus—Mikkola’s win confirmed his place among rallying’s elite and strengthened Ford’s foothold in the WRC championship.

title: 1979 Targa Florio – Rally di Sicilia (Italy)
bio: Tony Carello and Michele Perlasca tamed the legendary Sicilian mountain roads in their Lancia Stratos HF to win the 1979 Targa Florio Rally, showcasing precision and power on iconic tarmac.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Targa Florio – Rally di Sicilia

Date: March 16–18, 1979

Host Country: Italy

Surface: Tarmac

Total Distance: ~800 km

Total Starters: Approx. 70 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

A modern rally tribute to one of motorsport’s oldest and most historic road races, the 1979 Targa Florio Rally ran on the tight, twisting mountain roads of Sicily. Featuring endless corners and elevation changes, the event demanded maximum precision. Tony Carello and Michele Perlasca delivered a strong, composed performance in the Lancia Stratos HF, a car bred for Italian tarmac, claiming victory against stiff local and international competition.

🗺️ Route Details

The route followed sections of the famed Piccolo Circuito delle Madonie, winding through Sicilian villages, ridges, and olive groves, with non-stop corners and few opportunities for rest.

  • Cerda to Collesano: Tight switchbacks and narrow lanes with minimal runoff.
  • Caltavuturo Stage: High-speed tarmac descent demanding absolute confidence in braking zones.
  • Madonie Highlands: Long climbs and steep drops kept drivers constantly adjusting rhythm and gearwork.

Spring sunshine provided mostly dry conditions, but dust, debris, and tight village crossings made for a technical and high-risk environment.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Tony Carello & Michele Perlasca (Lancia Stratos HF)

2nd Place: Adartico Vudafieri & Luigi Pirollo (Fiat 131 Abarth)

3rd Place: Mauro Pregliasco & Carlo Capone (Opel Kadett GT/E)

Carello’s mastery of the Stratos on narrow tarmac proved unbeatable in Sicily, with clean lines and consistent stage pace overcoming the field on one of Italy’s most historic courses.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Stratos HF: Compact, mid-engined, and perfectly suited to twisty mountain tarmac—agile and powerful.
  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Balanced and fast, but slightly heavier and less nimble in Sicily’s constant direction changes.
  • Opel Kadett GT/E: Strong performance from a privateer entry—reliable and quick on clean tarmac.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Corner Density: The sheer number of tight turns placed strain on pacenote delivery and driver concentration.
  • Urban Sections: Narrow village roads with blind exits tested timing and required total car control.
  • Brake Management: Constant deceleration over long descents pushed brake systems to their limits.

The 1979 Targa Florio proved a celebration of Sicily’s motorsport heritage—Carello’s win added another chapter to the Stratos’ legacy on home soil.

title: 1979 Rally Costa Smeralda (Italy)
bio: Antonio Fassina and Mauro Mannini mastered the rugged Sardinian gravel to claim victory at the 1979 Rally Costa Smeralda in their Lancia Stratos HF.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Rally Costa Smeralda

Date: April 4–6, 1979

Host Country: Italy

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~750 km

Total Starters: Approx. 60 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

Set against the dramatic landscape of Sardinia’s northeastern coast, the 1979 Rally Costa Smeralda delivered a tough mix of loose gravel, jagged rock edges, and sudden elevation changes. Antonio Fassina and Mauro Mannini utilized the powerful Lancia Stratos HF’s agility and traction to conquer the rough terrain and take home a confident victory in this gravel showcase of Italian rallying talent.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally was based around Olbia and the Gallura region, where winding mountain tracks and coastal dirt roads delivered a fast but technical challenge.

  • Gallura Hills: Narrow, winding trails with loose stones and frequent blind crests.
  • Coastal Sections: Open, fast gravel stretches lined with shrubbery and steep drops toward the sea.
  • Mountain Loops: Technical uphill climbs and sharp descents that tested traction and engine response.

Sunny, dry spring weather kept the stages dusty, with visibility issues for following cars and loose surfaces that punished even small driving errors.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Antonio Fassina & Mauro Mannini (Lancia Stratos HF)

2nd Place: Adartico Vudafieri & Luigi Pirollo (Fiat 131 Abarth)

3rd Place: Tonino Tognana & Massimo De Antoni (Opel Ascona B)

Fassina’s smooth driving and Mannini’s clean navigation made the difference, as the Stratos handled the abrasive terrain and relentless pace with ease.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Stratos HF: Mid-engined layout gave superb balance; its torque delivery and suspension made it ideal for Sardinia’s loose terrain.
  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Strong contender with good gravel performance, but struggled in tighter technical corners compared to the Stratos.
  • Opel Ascona B: Reliable and steady—less outright speed but capable of surviving rough terrain.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Loose Gravel: Unstable surfaces forced drivers to stay light on throttle and aggressive with weight transfer.
  • Rocky Outcrops: Tight lines were often punished by stones and ruts capable of damaging tires or suspension.
  • Visibility: Hanging dust created hazards for closely spaced competitors—clean air often determined pace.

The 1979 Rally Costa Smeralda proved a punishing yet rewarding event—Fassina’s control and the Stratos’ raw talent dominated the Sardinian gravel in dramatic fashion.

title: 1979 Saarland Rallye (West Germany)
bio: Walter Röhrl and Christian Geistdörfer secured victory at the 1979 Saarland Rallye, skillfully navigating the mixed-surface stages in their Fiat 131 Abarth.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Saarland Rallye

Date: April 5–7, 1979

Host Country: West Germany

Surface: Mixed (Tarmac / Gravel)

Total Distance: ~850 km

Total Starters: Approx. 65 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

Held in the hilly border region between Germany and France, the 1979 Saarland Rallye challenged crews with its unpredictable surface changes and tight, technical stages. The terrain shifted between fast asphalt sections and loose gravel paths through vineyards and forests. Walter Röhrl and Christian Geistdörfer delivered a composed and confident drive in their Fiat 131 Abarth, making the most of their home soil advantage to take the win.

🗺️ Route Details

The route took competitors through the rolling hills and narrow roads of the Saarland region, with varied terrain demanding sharp focus and adaptable setups.

  • Vineyard Roads: Tight tarmac lanes with blind corners and loose debris from farming traffic.
  • Forest Gravel Sections: Soft underfoot and muddy in places—ideal for testing throttle control and tire wear.
  • Rural Transits: High-speed links between stages required teams to manage cooling and fuel strategy carefully.

Weather was mixed, with cool spring rain making surface grip unpredictable and increasing the complexity of tire choices throughout the event.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Walter Röhrl & Christian Geistdörfer (Fiat 131 Abarth)

2nd Place: Sepp Haider & Ferdi Hinterleitner (Opel Ascona B)

3rd Place: Harald Demuth & Peter Diekmann (Audi 80 GTE)

Röhrl’s local experience and Geistdörfer’s precise co-driving were key to managing the rally’s varied terrain and quick changes in stage character.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Excellent on tarmac and stable on gravel—its robust suspension and responsive engine proved ideal for the mixed stages.
  • Opel Ascona B: Well-balanced and reliable with a strong showing from Haider on local roads.
  • Audi 80 GTE: Lightweight and agile, though slightly underpowered compared to factory-backed opposition.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Variable Surfaces: Quick transitions between tarmac and gravel kept suspension and tire setups under pressure.
  • Grip Inconsistency: Patchy spring rain made some stages change conditions between recce and run.
  • Fast Reactions: Short, twisty stages demanded rapid pacenote delivery and instant responses from both driver and co-driver.

The 1979 Saarland Rallye showcased Röhrl and Geistdörfer’s rising dominance, combining local terrain knowledge with the Fiat 131 Abarth’s all-surface capability to secure a decisive victory.

title: 1979 Safari Rally (Kenya)
bio: Shekhar Mehta and Mike Doughty overcame Africa’s harshest conditions to win the 1979 Safari Rally in their Datsun 160J, marking Mehta’s third triumph in the legendary endurance event.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 27th Safari Rally

Date: April 12–16, 1979

Host Country: Kenya

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~5,000 km

Total Starters: Approx. 74 crews

Total Finishers: 18 crews

The 1979 Safari Rally remained the WRC’s ultimate test of durability and endurance. Run across Kenya’s vast landscapes, it featured rocky plains, river crossings, and unpredictable weather that turned dirt roads into rivers within minutes. Local hero Shekhar Mehta, with co-driver Mike Doughty, expertly navigated the chaos in their Datsun 160J (Violet), claiming his third Safari win and adding to Nissan’s growing African rally legacy.

🗺️ Route Details

The route circled out from Nairobi and looped through Nakuru, Eldoret, Kisumu, and down toward Mombasa before returning inland—covering every terrain from volcanic rock to dense bush and tropical rain.

  • Rift Valley: Harsh gravel and lava rock fields caused frequent tire and suspension failures.
  • Equatorial Rain Zones: Sudden thunderstorms created impassable mud tracks and flash-flooded crossings.
  • High-Speed Open Sections: Flat plains offered high average speeds but increased the risk of wildlife encounters.

Weather was a key factor, with storms reshaping the road surface hour by hour—only crews with excellent local knowledge and mechanical sympathy could survive the changing conditions.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Shekhar Mehta & Mike Doughty (Datsun 160J)

2nd Place: Sandro Munari & Silvio Maiga (Lancia Stratos HF)

3rd Place: Rauno Aaltonen & Lofty Drews (Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé)

Mehta’s precise navigation and smooth pacing across punishing terrain proved unbeatable—his experience in African endurance rallying gave him an edge unmatched by even the top European stars.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Datsun 160J (Violet): Exceptionally robust and reliable—its high ground clearance and tough suspension system made it ideal for Safari conditions.
  • Lancia Stratos HF: Fast and aggressive, but struggled with mechanical reliability in the punishing heat and dust.
  • Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé: Strong on long straights and rough terrain, though slightly slower through tight bush sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Flooding & Washouts: Entire sections disappeared under water, forcing reroutes and delays.
  • Mechanical Attrition: Heat, dust, and constant vibration pushed every component to the breaking point.
  • Local Knowledge: Only teams with deep familiarity of Kenya’s terrain and conditions could maintain competitive pace while minimizing risks.

The 1979 Safari Rally confirmed Shekhar Mehta as one of Africa’s greatest rally drivers—his blend of pace, caution, and local instinct proved unbeatable in rallying’s toughest contest.

title: 1979 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Björn Waldegård and Hans Thorszelius conquered Greece’s punishing gravel and heat in the 1979 Acropolis Rally, earning a hard-fought win in their Ford Escort RS1800.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 26th Acropolis Rally

Date: May 28–31, 1979

Host Country: Greece

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~2,800 km

Total Starters: Approx. 80 crews

Total Finishers: 24 crews

The Acropolis Rally is legendary for its unforgiving conditions, and the 1979 edition was no exception. Dry, rocky stages under the scorching Greek sun pushed drivers and machinery to the brink. Björn Waldegård and Hans Thorszelius delivered a masterclass in mechanical preservation and high-speed gravel driving, taking victory in their Ford Escort RS1800 in one of the most demanding events on the WRC calendar.

🗺️ Route Details

Based out of Athens, the route wound through central and southern Greece, with rough mountain trails and blistering plains punishing suspension and navigation alike.

  • Mount Parnassus & Lamia: Rocky mountain stages with long climbs, tight hairpins, and large boulder hazards.
  • Peloponnese Region: Fast, dusty tracks that severely tested air filters, cooling, and tires.
  • Parnitha & Attica Loops: Shorter, twistier stages near Athens—technical but no less punishing.

Midday heat routinely exceeded 35°C, creating a brutal test for crews who had to keep a relentless pace without overdriving fragile components.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Björn Waldegård & Hans Thorszelius (Ford Escort RS1800)

2nd Place: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Ford Escort RS1800)

3rd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Fiat 131 Abarth)

Waldegård’s clean and calculated approach kept him ahead of teammate Mikkola, while many other favorites succumbed to mechanical issues or off-road excursions in the merciless Greek terrain.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS1800: Strong suspension and light weight made it the perfect weapon for Greece’s rough and hot conditions.
  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Fast but fragile under extreme conditions—several suffered overheating and suspension issues.
  • Porsche 911 SC: Competitive on smoother gravel, but struggled on the sharp rocks and with cooling in the heat.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Sharp Rocks: Frequent punctures and underbody damage punished aggressive lines.
  • Heat & Dust: Interior temps soared, and dust clouds could linger for minutes—visibility and breathing were serious concerns.
  • Endurance Pace: Teams had to maintain strong speed over four brutal days without overdriving—mechanical attrition eliminated many fast contenders.

The 1979 Acropolis Rally was a trial by fire—Waldegård’s victory came from calm control and mechanical preservation on one of the WRC’s harshest proving grounds.

title: 1979 Rally of New Zealand (New Zealand)
bio: Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz dominated the 1979 Rally of New Zealand, showcasing mastery across the country's scenic and challenging mix of gravel and tarmac in their Ford Escort RS1800.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 18th Rally of New Zealand

Date: July 14–18, 1979

Host Country: New Zealand

Surface: Mixed Tarmac / Gravel

Total Distance: ~2,200 km

Total Starters: Approx. 80 crews

Total Finishers: 28 crews

The 1979 Rally of New Zealand presented a stunning blend of coastal highways, rolling countryside, and fast-flowing forest roads. Stretching across New Zealand’s North Island, the rally was a test of driver adaptability with its frequent surface changes and weather shifts. Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz delivered a near-flawless performance in their Ford Escort RS1800, securing victory with smooth transitions between tight technical sections and high-speed open stretches.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally toured from Auckland through Rotorua and into the Waikato and Bay of Plenty regions, mixing coastal tarmac stages with fast, flowing gravel tracks through pine forests and farmland.

  • Kinleith Forest: Smooth, well-cambered gravel roads ideal for fast cornering and rhythm.
  • Coromandel Peninsula: Tarmac mountain passes with tight switchbacks and scenic overlooks.
  • Rotorua Region: Volcanic soil created slippery gravel stages when wet—demanding tire strategy and finesse.

New Zealand’s winter weather brought unpredictable rain showers, meaning grip levels changed from stage to stage. Teams needed flexible setups and quick adaptation to shifting conditions.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Ford Escort RS1800)

2nd Place: Ari Vatanen & Peter Bryant (Ford Escort RS1800)

3rd Place: Tony Pond & Fred Gallagher (Triumph TR7 V8)

Mikkola and Hertz’s clean and commanding pace kept them ahead throughout, with smooth driving and excellent teamwork on both surfaces proving decisive against fierce competition.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS1800: Equally capable on tarmac and gravel—its agility and dependability made it the ideal car for New Zealand’s mixed terrain.
  • Triumph TR7 V8: Powerful on tarmac but less agile on gravel, though Tony Pond’s driving pushed it to a strong podium result.
  • Datsun 160J: Well-balanced and reliable, but slightly down on power compared to the factory-backed Escorts.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Changing Weather: Alternating dry and rainy conditions required teams to adapt tire pressure and suspension on the fly.
  • Gravel-Tarmac Transitions: Maintaining rhythm through changing grip levels was critical to overall pace.
  • Fast Stages: High average speeds meant that even small mistakes could lead to major time losses—or retirement.

The 1979 Rally of New Zealand highlighted the Escort RS1800’s dominance and Mikkola’s world-class consistency, cementing their place atop the WRC field.

title: 1979 Codasur Rally (Argentina)
bio: Walter Röhrl and Christian Geistdörfer triumphed in the inaugural Codasur Rally in Argentina, tackling South America’s fast and rugged gravel with precision in their Fiat 131 Abarth.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Codasur Rally (Rally Argentina)

Date: July 19–26, 1979

Host Country: Argentina

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~3,000 km

Total Starters: Approx. 80 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

Though officially part of the 1980 WRC season, the 1979 Codasur Rally marked a key milestone in rally history as Argentina made its debut on the world stage. With vast distances, high-speed gravel roads, and mountainous terrain, the event previewed the fierce nature of South American rallying. Walter Röhrl and Christian Geistdörfer adapted quickly, guiding their Fiat 131 Abarth to a historic win and setting the tone for future WRC competition in the region.

🗺️ Route Details

Centered around Córdoba, the route included a mix of open plains, rough Pampas trails, and winding mountain stages through the Sierras de Córdoba region.

  • Villa Carlos Paz Loops: Fast gravel with sweeping turns and long straights across the countryside.
  • Traslasierra Range: Narrow mountain passes with switchbacks, drop-offs, and changing elevations.
  • Chaco and Santa Fe Sections: Rougher, flatter terrain with loose surfaces and deep dust trails.

Dry mid-winter weather dominated the rally, creating high dust levels and warm daytime temperatures, but clear conditions helped ensure fast-paced competition across most stages.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Walter Röhrl & Christian Geistdörfer (Fiat 131 Abarth)

2nd Place: Jorge Recalde & Rodolfo 'Cacho' Ambrosio (Fiat 131 Abarth)

3rd Place: Ricardo Zunino & Juan Carlos Iglesias (Renault 18 GTX)

Röhrl’s disciplined pace and Geistdörfer’s calm control through long stages brought the European team ahead of strong local talent, including Argentine ace Jorge Recalde.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Balanced, robust, and suited for high-speed gravel—ideal for the long distances and heavy braking zones of Argentine stages.
  • Renault 18 GTX: Local favorite with strong torque and durability, though less competitive in tighter technical stages.
  • Datsun 160J: A popular privateer entry, capable of absorbing rough terrain with solid reliability.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Distance & Fatigue: Long, remote stages required careful energy management and flawless navigation over hundreds of kilometers per day.
  • Dust Clouds: Dry winter roads left a trail of hanging dust, compromising visibility and requiring larger starting gaps.
  • Mechanical Endurance: Rock-strewn tracks and inconsistent surfaces demanded constant attention to tire and suspension wear.

The 1979 Codasur Rally proved South America’s capacity to host world-class rallying—Röhrl’s win paved the way for Argentina’s permanent role in the WRC calendar starting in 1980.

title: 1979 Danube Rally (Romania)
bio: Jean-Claude Andruet and “Biche” secured a dominant win in the 1979 Danube Rally, taming Romania’s fast and dusty gravel stages in their Lancia Stratos HF.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Danube Rally

Date: August 1979

Host Country: Romania

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~1,200 km

Total Starters: Approx. 60 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

The 1979 Danube Rally, one of Eastern Europe’s most prominent events, provided a high-speed challenge across Romania’s diverse countryside. Combining long straights with twisty forest sections, the rally demanded confidence and technical adaptability. French pairing Jean-Claude Andruet and “Biche” drove with precision and pace, capturing the win in their powerful and nimble Lancia Stratos HF against a field of experienced Eastern Bloc and Western European competitors.

🗺️ Route Details

The route featured stages near the Carpathian foothills and the Danube River basin, blending fast open gravel with narrow village roads and rugged climbs.

  • Southern Plains: Flat-out gravel straights with limited braking zones and flowing bends.
  • Hill Climb Sections: Rocky gradients demanded throttle control and punished suspension setups.
  • Village Crossings: Narrow lanes with mixed surfaces and hidden junctions added to the challenge.

Dry summer conditions created dusty roads and loose surfaces throughout the event, favoring aggressive but calculated driving with good tire management.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jean-Claude Andruet & “Biche” (Lancia Stratos HF)

2nd Place: Simo Lampinen & Jaakko Markula (Saab 99 EMS)

3rd Place: Constantin Aur & Marin Dumitrescu (Dacia 1300)

Andruet’s relentless pace and “Biche’s” precise co-driving helped keep the Lancia ahead despite the fast local competition and changing terrain.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Stratos HF: Its short wheelbase and mid-engine balance excelled on tight gravel and rapid changes in direction.
  • Saab 99 EMS: Excellent traction and torque delivery made it competitive, especially on uphill sections.
  • Dacia 1300: Local reliability and handling knowledge gave Romanian teams strong showings on home soil.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Variable Terrain: Fast transitions from wide gravel to rough hill tracks kept drivers alert.
  • Visibility: Thick dust clouds often lingered over open stages, complicating overtakes and pacenote timing.
  • Mechanical Wear: Repeated rough descents and long straights tested brakes, cooling, and drivetrains.

The 1979 Danube Rally was a triumph of precision and teamwork—Andruet and “Biche’s” performance showcased the Stratos’ agility and their own elite rally instincts on Romania’s unforgiving roads.

title: 1979 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: Markku Alén and Ilkka Kivimäki soared to victory at the 1979 1000 Lakes Rally, expertly navigating Finland’s fast gravel jumps and sweeping corners in their Fiat 131 Abarth.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 29th 1000 Lakes Rally

Date: August 24–28, 1979

Host Country: Finland

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~1,600 km

Total Starters: Approx. 120 crews

Total Finishers: 54 crews

The 1000 Lakes Rally, now known as Rally Finland, is famed for its high-speed gravel roads and airborne crests. The 1979 edition lived up to its reputation, with lightning-fast stages and precision pacenoting separating the best from the rest. Local favorite Markku Alén, with co-driver Ilkka Kivimäki, delivered a stunningly fast and controlled drive in their Fiat 131 Abarth, winning against one of the strongest lineups of the season on home soil.

🗺️ Route Details

Based in Jyväskylä, the route flew through central Finland’s forests and countryside, with classic stages like Ouninpohja, Laukaa, and Ruuhimäki testing commitment and rhythm.

  • Ouninpohja: Fast crests and tight landings demanded bravery and precise pacenotes.
  • Lankamaa & Laukaa: Flowing corners and thick forests at full throttle made for thrilling competition.
  • Ruuhimäki: Famous for its final jump and flat-out approach—ideal for photo finishes and split-second time gaps.

Conditions were near-perfect: dry, hard-packed gravel and long summer days provided maximum grip and visibility across all stages.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Fiat 131 Abarth)

2nd Place: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Ford Escort RS1800)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Peter Bryant (Ford Escort RS1800)

Alén’s superior commitment and deep local knowledge gave him the edge over Mikkola and Vatanen, with near-flawless stage times and maximum attack over every crest.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Balanced and stable at high speeds with excellent suspension travel—perfect for Finland’s jumps and ruts.
  • Ford Escort RS1800: Agile and responsive, but slightly edged out by the Fiat on long high-speed stages.
  • Saab 99 Turbo: Competitive in the hands of local drivers, but lacked consistency over longer loops.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Flat-Out Rhythm: High average speeds demanded precise notes and trust between driver and co-driver.
  • Jumps & Compression: Long airborne sections stressed suspension setups and landing alignment.
  • Split-Second Margins: Dozens of stage wins were decided by under a second—mistakes were costly and rare.

The 1979 1000 Lakes Rally was a showcase of Finnish rally mastery—Markku Alén’s fearless commitment and car control made him untouchable on the world’s fastest gravel rally.

title: 1979 Critérium Molson du Québec (Canada)
bio: Björn Waldegård and Hans Thorszelius claimed victory at the 1979 Critérium Molson du Québec, conquering Canada’s challenging mix of gravel and tarmac stages in their Ford Escort RS1800.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Critérium Molson du Québec

Date: September 13–16, 1979

Host Country: Canada

Surface: Mixed Gravel / Tarmac

Total Distance: ~1,250 km

Total Starters: Approx. 60 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

The 1979 Critérium Molson du Québec delivered a demanding test of car control and endurance across Canada’s varied terrain. With rapid surface transitions, changing elevations, and early autumn weather, the event rewarded versatility and consistency. Björn Waldegård and Hans Thorszelius delivered a composed and fast performance in their Ford Escort RS1800, maintaining pace across gravel forests and twisting paved roads to secure a key win in their championship campaign.

🗺️ Route Details

Based in Quebec, the rally included stages through the Laurentian Mountains, dense pine forests, and rural road networks near Montreal and Trois-Rivières.

  • Laurentian Loops: Fast gravel with elevation changes and soft shoulders.
  • Mont-Tremblant Area: Tarmac hill sections with technical braking zones and tight bends.
  • Mixed-Use Trails: Logging roads and unsealed tracks required adaptive driving across sudden transitions.

Cool, crisp weather created mostly dry conditions, though intermittent rain and falling leaves added variability to stage grip and visibility.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Björn Waldegård & Hans Thorszelius (Ford Escort RS1800)

2nd Place: Jean-Paul Perusse & Yvon Dufour (Datsun 710)

3rd Place: John Buffum & Doug Shepherd (Audi 80 GLE)

Waldegård’s pace and precision were unmatched, with Thorszelius providing faultless navigation through a complex set of stages spread across multiple surface types.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS1800: Proven on both gravel and tarmac, the Escort’s agility and durability gave it the upper hand across Canada’s mixed roads.
  • Datsun 710: Reliable and efficient with good torque for forest stages, though less nimble in tight paved sections.
  • Audi 80 GLE: Competitive and composed on smoother stages, with front-wheel drive helping in slippery zones.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Mixed Surfaces: Abrupt transitions from gravel to tarmac required flexible driving and careful brake management.
  • Changing Elevations: Forest stages climbed and dropped quickly, stressing engines and brakes alike.
  • Autumn Debris: Wet leaves and mud on paved roads introduced unpredictable grip loss in fast corners.

The 1979 Critérium Molson du Québec was a decisive victory for Waldegård—his balance of speed and control on Canada’s diverse roads reinforced his world-class versatility.

title: 1979 Tap Rallye Internacional do Brasil (Brazil)
bio: British driver Jim Clark piloted a Volkswagen to victory in the 1979 Tap Rallye Internacional do Brasil, showcasing precision and endurance across Brazil’s fast and rugged gravel roads.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Tap Rallye Internacional do Brasil

Date: September 1979

Host Country: Brazil

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~1,400 km

Total Starters: Approx. 50 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

The 1979 Tap Rallye Internacional do Brasil was part of South America’s growing motorsport presence, featuring long gravel stages through Brazil’s varied terrain. Jim Clark, driving for Volkswagen, delivered a focused and consistent performance across difficult road conditions to claim an impressive win, fending off both local and international challengers.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally took place primarily in southeastern Brazil, with stages near São Paulo and Minas Gerais, combining wide red-earth roads and narrow jungle tracks.

  • Interior Farm Roads: Dry, fast, and dusty—with sharp ruts and loose stones at high speed.
  • Mountain Slopes: Rough uphill and downhill sectors required careful gearwork and braking technique.
  • Jungle Sections: Dense vegetation, tight curves, and variable visibility made these stages unpredictable.

Springtime conditions brought warm temperatures and dry terrain, though late-afternoon storms were known to complicate later stages.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jim Clark (Volkswagen)

2nd Place: Paulo Gomes (Chevrolet Opala)

3rd Place: Alcides Diniz (Fiat 147)

Clark’s consistency and focus allowed him to avoid mechanical setbacks while others faltered—his pace through the middle sectors gave him the edge on accumulated time.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Volkswagen: Lightweight and dependable, with strong cooling and suspension suited to Brazilian gravel.
  • Chevrolet Opala: Fast in a straight line but struggled in narrow sections due to bulk and braking limitations.
  • Fiat 147: Agile and responsive—favored in twisty jungle stages but down on power over longer straights.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Red Clay Dust: Reduced visibility and made braking less predictable—especially late in the day.
  • Mechanical Preservation: Suspension damage and overheating were major issues for less prepared teams.
  • Local Terrain Knowledge: Helped Brazilian drivers navigate deceptive corners and tricky surface transitions.

The 1979 Tap Rallye Internacional do Brasil highlighted South America’s potential for high-level rallying—Jim Clark’s steady hand and Volkswagen’s rugged setup proved a winning combination on Brazil’s demanding roads.

title: 1979 Rallye Sanremo (Italy)
bio: Antonio “Tony” Fassina and Mauro Mannini delivered a heroic drive to win the 1979 Rallye Sanremo in their Lancia Stratos HF, mastering the complex mix of tarmac and gravel stages along Italy’s Ligurian coast.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 21º Rallye Sanremo

Date: October 1–7, 1979

Host Country: Italy

Surface: Mixed Tarmac / Gravel

Total Distance: ~1,850 km

Total Starters: Approx. 100 crews

Total Finishers: 36 crews

The 1979 Rallye Sanremo was a classic Italian battleground, challenging drivers with a blend of rough gravel climbs and tight coastal tarmac. Known for its unpredictable transitions and beautiful yet brutal terrain, it tested adaptability and endurance. Antonio “Tony” Fassina, driving a privateer Lancia Stratos HF with co-driver Mauro Mannini, shocked the factory teams with a commanding win—one of the most memorable privateer victories in WRC history.

🗺️ Route Details

Based in Sanremo on the Italian Riviera, the rally featured rugged inland mountain loops and asphalt stages carved into the coastline, with surface changes often within the same stage.

  • Dolceacqua & Bajardo: Gravel-heavy mountain roads with tight switchbacks and exposed drops.
  • Colle d’Oggia & Passo Teglia: Mixed-surface stages requiring rapid tire and setup adjustments.
  • Coastal Loops: Narrow tarmac routes with scenic views and dangerous cliffs.

Autumn rains occasionally hit the higher elevations, creating slick gravel and muddy transitions, adding unpredictability to an already complex rally.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Antonio “Tony” Fassina & Mauro Mannini (Lancia Stratos HF)

2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Fiat 131 Abarth)

3rd Place: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Ford Escort RS1800)

Fassina’s composed performance stunned the factory-backed teams, delivering the Lancia Stratos its final WRC victory in grand fashion.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Stratos HF: Agile, powerful, and purpose-built for these narrow roads—still competitive despite its aging design.
  • Fiat 131 Abarth: Well-balanced on both surfaces, but lacked the explosive tarmac performance of the Stratos.
  • Ford Escort RS1800: Reliable and consistent across gravel stages, though slightly disadvantaged on twisty tarmac.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Changes: Frequent transitions required careful setup compromises and quick driving adjustments.
  • Weather Variability: Rain in upper stages caused grip issues, while lower tarmac stayed dry and fast.
  • Privateer Pressure: Fassina had to outperform full-factory efforts without backup or service parity—a true underdog victory.

The 1979 Rallye Sanremo remains a legendary rally—Fassina’s drive marked the end of an era for the Stratos and proved that brilliance behind the wheel could still overcome factory dominance.

title: 1979 Southern Cross Rally (Australia)
bio: Ross Dunkerton and Geoff Jones claimed victory in the 1979 Southern Cross Rally, mastering Australia’s demanding gravel terrain in their Datsun 710 (Stanza) with a performance of precision and endurance.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1979 Southern Cross Rally

Date: October 1979

Host Country: Australia

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~2,000 km

Total Starters: Approx. 50 crews

Total Finishers: N/A

The 1979 Southern Cross Rally tested crews with long competitive distances and rugged Australian conditions. Stretching from Sydney up the New South Wales coast into the forests and ranges inland, the rally was known for its endurance format and unpredictable terrain. Ross Dunkerton and Geoff Jones delivered a consistent and tactical performance in their Datsun 710 (Stanza), defeating a competitive field on home soil with a measured mix of speed and mechanical sympathy.

🗺️ Route Details

Starting near Sydney, the route passed through towns like Coffs Harbour, Kempsey, and Armidale, with grueling stages in coastal forests, dry plains, and rugged hills.

  • State Forest Trails: Narrow gravel tracks with soft surfaces and tight corners.
  • Armidale Highlands: Faster flowing sections with jumps, cattle grids, and creek crossings.
  • Night Stages: Long competitive sections after dark increased the physical and mental demands on crews.

Dry spring weather dominated, but occasional dust storms and wildlife crossings added unexpected hazards throughout the rally.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Ross Dunkerton & Geoff Jones (Datsun 710)

2nd Place: George Fury & Monty Suffern (Datsun 710)

3rd Place: Colin Bond & Garry Connelly (Ford Escort RS2000)

Dunkerton’s calm pace and smooth technique allowed him to edge out teammate George Fury, while many rivals faced attrition on the long and punishing route.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Datsun 710 (Stanza): Strong suspension, excellent reliability, and responsive power delivery made it a favorite for Australian conditions.
  • Ford Escort RS2000: Quick on tighter sections, but struggled with durability over longer rough stages.
  • Holden Gemini: Agile and competitive, though down on power and prone to mechanical issues under pressure.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Endurance Format: Long hours behind the wheel with limited service made fatigue a key factor.
  • Variable Terrain: Sudden transitions between forest, plains, and hills tested suspension tuning and pace judgment.
  • Dust & Wildlife: Hanging dust clouds and animal crossings demanded extreme concentration at high speed.

The 1979 Southern Cross Rally exemplified the spirit of endurance rallying—Dunkerton’s victory solidified his reputation as one of Australia’s premier rally drivers, and further proved the Datsun 710’s strength in one of the sport’s toughest regional contests.

title: 1979 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Bernard Darniche and Alain Mahé delivered a masterful drive to win the 1979 Tour de Corse, dominating the twisty Corsican asphalt in their Lancia Stratos HF.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 23ème Tour de Corse

Date: November 2–4, 1979

Host Country: France

Surface: Asphalt

Total Distance: ~1,100 km

Total Starters: Approx. 80 crews

Total Finishers: 30 crews

Known as the “Rally of 10,000 Corners,” the 1979 Tour de Corse once again proved to be a brutal test of endurance and concentration. With its narrow mountain roads and relentless curves across the Corsican island, the rally pushed drivers to the limit. Bernard Darniche, a Corsican asphalt specialist, paired with Alain Mahé to pilot their Lancia Stratos HF to a dominant victory, demonstrating smooth car control and precise pace all weekend long.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages wound through the mountainous interior of Corsica, connecting coastal villages and hilltop passes with little room for error and minimal guardrails.

  • Ajaccio Loops: Technical, twisty tarmac with steep drop-offs and constant direction changes.
  • Corte & Bastia Regions: Tight uphill hairpins and rapid descents that punished over-braking and understeering.
  • Balagne Coast: Fast, scenic stretches punctuated by rough patches and narrow urban sections.

The weather remained clear and dry throughout the event, offering ideal conditions but exposing drivers to full-speed consequences for the slightest mistake.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Bernard Darniche & Alain Mahé (Lancia Stratos HF)

2nd Place: Guy Fréquelin & Jean Todt (Talbot Sunbeam Lotus)

3rd Place: Jean Ragnotti & Jean-Marc Andrié (Renault 5 Alpine)

Darniche’s win on home territory was commanding—his smooth rhythm and absolute trust in Mahé’s notes allowed them to stay ahead of newer machinery on the unforgiving Corsican roads.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Stratos HF: Short wheelbase and powerful V6 made it perfect for Corsican hairpins, despite its aging design.
  • Talbot Sunbeam Lotus: Light and nimble with a modern chassis—fast on technical sections but lacking the outright power of the Stratos.
  • Renault 5 Alpine: Competitive in the hands of Ragnotti—great handling, but lower top speed limited long-stage potential.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Endless Corners: Drivers were in constant motion—fatigue and concentration lapses were common by the final day.
  • Minimal Margins: Little to no runoff or recovery space meant precision was critical to avoid disaster.
  • Mechanical Load: Brakes, tires, and gearboxes were pushed to their limits by the terrain’s continuous elevation changes.

The 1979 Tour de Corse was a vintage performance from Bernard Darniche and a triumphant send-off for the Lancia Stratos HF on one of the world’s most demanding tarmac rallies.

title: 1979 Lombard RAC Rally (United Kingdom)
bio: Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz triumphed in treacherous British forests to win the 1979 Lombard RAC Rally in their Ford Escort RS1800, concluding the season with a dominant gravel performance.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 28th Lombard RAC Rally

Date: November 18–21, 1979

Host Country: United Kingdom

Surface: Gravel

Total Distance: ~2,000 km

Total Starters: Approx. 160 crews

Total Finishers: 75 crews

The 1979 Lombard RAC Rally brought the WRC season to a dramatic close, with Britain's legendary forest stages shrouded in mist, mud, and rain. The event’s trademark of no pacenotes and marathon routing across England, Wales, and southern Scotland made for an intense test of driver memory, reflexes, and co-driver efficiency. Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz emerged victorious in their Ford Escort RS1800, mastering the rally’s ever-changing grip and visibility conditions with poise and speed.

🗺️ Route Details

With a ceremonial start in Bath, the rally journeyed through forests in Wales, Yorkshire, Kielder, and the Lake District. Overnight transits, service parks in muddy fields, and dawn restarts pushed teams to the brink.

  • Dyfi & Hafren Forests: Wet, rutted gravel with tricky cambers and minimal lighting.
  • Grizedale & Kielder: Fast-flowing forest tracks with sudden changes in elevation and surface grip.
  • Yorkshire Moors: Fog-prone moorland roads, open and quick but prone to slick patches and low visibility.

Rain, fog, and frost greeted competitors on nearly every leg. With no pace notes allowed, recce-free stages meant co-drivers relied solely on road books, heightening the challenge.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Ford Escort RS1800)

2nd Place: Björn Waldegård & Hans Thorszelius (Ford Escort RS1800)

3rd Place: Russell Brookes & Mike Broad (Ford Escort RS1800)

Mikkola’s experience and steady hand on slippery British gravel kept him just ahead of teammate Waldegård, sealing a crucial win to round off the season with Ford dominance.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS1800: Proven on muddy UK terrain—agile, tough, and perfectly suited to RAC’s rough forest stages.
  • Talbot Sunbeam Lotus: Fast and agile in the right hands, but a relative newcomer to top-level endurance rallies.
  • Opel Kadett GT/E: Competitive in drier sections but lacked consistency in the deepest forest mud.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • No Recce Policy: Crews relied entirely on road books and timing sheets—requiring exceptional memory and reaction.
  • Mud & Rain: Constant grip changes required intuitive car control and maximum throttle modulation.
  • Night Stages: Over half the rally ran in darkness—visibility, fatigue, and spotlight placement became major factors.

The 1979 RAC Rally demanded endurance, discipline, and adaptability—Mikkola’s triumph closed out the decade with a definitive masterclass in classic British rallying.

title: 1979 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire (Ivory Coast)
bio: Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz braved sweltering heat, rough terrain, and marathon distances to win the 1979 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire in their Mercedes-Benz 450 SLC 5.0.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 11ème Rallye Côte d’Ivoire

Date: December 9–14, 1979

Host Country: Ivory Coast

Surface: Mixed Tarmac / Gravel

Total Distance: ~5,300 km

Total Starters: Approx. 49 crews

Total Finishers: 13 crews

The 1979 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire was one of the most grueling endurance rallies of the season, second only to the Safari Rally in terms of length and mechanical attrition. Covering over 5,000 km of blistering terrain in West Africa, the event required stamina, heat resistance, and absolute mechanical discipline. Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz rose to the challenge in their powerful Mercedes-Benz 450 SLC 5.0, driving with precision and endurance to claim victory after six days of punishing rallying.

🗺️ Route Details

The route looped across the Ivory Coast, passing through Abidjan, Bouaké, Yamoussoukro, and remote jungle regions—mixing wide open tarmac roads with rugged gravel trails, river crossings, and village detours.

  • Coastal Highways: Long tarmac stretches through sweltering humidity tested cooling systems and tire durability.
  • Inland Jungle Trails: Broken gravel tracks and forest paths where sharp rocks and deep ruts punished careless driving.
  • Village Crossings: Narrow, dusty passes through populated areas required awareness and mechanical sympathy.

Temperatures soared above 35°C, and even at night, dust clouds and tropical humidity presented relentless challenges to both driver and car.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Mercedes-Benz 450 SLC 5.0)

2nd Place: Andrew Cowan & Klaus Kaiser (Mercedes-Benz 450 SLC 5.0)

3rd Place: Alain Ambrosino & Jean-Pierre Nicolas (Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé)

Mikkola and Hertz led a strong Mercedes-Benz effort, with their experience in African rallies proving vital as they withstood mechanical punishment and navigational complexity across thousands of kilometers.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mercedes-Benz 450 SLC 5.0: Heavy but exceptionally robust—its V8 power, long-range fuel tanks, and reinforced suspension made it ideal for long African endurance rallies.
  • Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé: Excellent on rough roads with proven reliability in African conditions, though lacking the raw speed of the Mercedes.
  • Datsun 160J: Lightweight and consistent, but struggled to match the outright pace of the factory-backed entries.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Heat: Constant engine temperature monitoring and cabin ventilation were critical to avoid retirement or heat exhaustion.
  • Fatigue Management: Multiple 20+ hour driving legs made mental clarity and pacing as important as outright speed.
  • Navigation: Roadbooks were often unclear, and missed junctions could mean huge time losses or disqualification.

The 1979 Côte d’Ivoire Rally showcased Mikkola and Hertz’s elite stamina and strategic brilliance—their victory was a testament to calculated endurance in one of the world’s toughest motorsport events.
